channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Ukrainian officials raise warnings about Russia’s Victory Day as heavy fighting continues in east
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: Ukrainian officials say debris is being cleared as Russians plan to turn Mariupol into the center of “celebrations” for Victory Day on May 9.

item.title: Kremlin is targeting Ukraine resupply infrastructure, officials say
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner
item.description: The Kremlin is carrying out strikes on infrastructure that is critical to Ukraine’s efforts to resupply its forces in their defense against Russia’s invasion, Ukrainian officials and the Pentagon said.

item.title: Leader of Haitian gang behind missionary abductions is charged in U.S.
item.dc:creator: Widlore Mérancourt
item.description: Germine Joly, also known as “Yonyon,” allegedly ran 400 Mawozo from his prison cell.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live updates: Ukrainian officials raise warnings about Russia’s Victory Day as heavy fighting continues in east
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: Ukrainian officials say debris is being cleared as Russians plan to turn Mariupol into the center of “celebrations” for Victory Day on May 9.

item.title: Kremlin is targeting Ukraine resupply infrastructure, officials say
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner
item.description: The Kremlin is carrying out strikes on infrastructure that is critical to Ukraine’s efforts to resupply its forces in their defense against Russia’s invasion, Ukrainian officials and the Pentagon said.

item.title: Leader of Haitian gang behind missionary abductions is charged in U.S.
item.dc:creator: Widlore Mérancourt
item.description: Germine Joly, also known as “Yonyon,” allegedly ran 400 Mawozo from his prison cell.

item.title: Scrapping Roe would affect both sides of border, Canadian official says
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger
item.description: Abortion is legal in Canada, though access remains scarce for many outside of urban centers.

item.title: Mexico will take back more Cubans and Nicaraguans expelled by U.S.
item.dc:creator: Nick Miroff
item.description: The deal is potentially significant because the Mexican government has more latitude to carry out deportation flights to Cuba and Nicaragua, nations whose frosty relations with Washington severely limit the United States’ ability to return their citizens.

item.title: E.U. proposes ban on Russian oil imports by end of year
item.dc:creator: Emily Rauhala
item.description: The plan, announced by European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, has been circulated to E.U. diplomats and could be approved this week.

item.title: Don’t be ‘Putin’s altar boy,’ Pope warns Russian Orthodox leader
item.dc:creator: Timothy Bella
item.description: During their conversation, Pope Francis said, Russian Orthodox Church leader Patriarch Kirill was listing off all the justifications for the war from a sheet of paper he was holding.

item.title: Maps of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Washington Post Staff
item.description: Russia has launched an extensive assault on Ukraine. We're mapping how Russian troops are advancing.

item.title: What Victory Day means for Russian identity
item.dc:creator: Lateshia Beachum
item.description: May 9, known as Victory Day for Russians, could signal the end of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine or something more frightful that’s unlikely to halt the violence, but it's all speculation at this point.

item.title: Stanislav Shushkevich, who led Belarus to independence, dies at 87
item.dc:creator: From Staff and Wire Reports
item.description: He was a harsh critic of Alexander Lukashenko, the authoritarian who succeeded him as the new nation’s leader in 1994.

item.title: Russian ally Belarus launches military quick-response drills
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong
item.description: The border with Russia's ally is “constantly being strengthened,” a Ukrainian official said.

item.title: Ukrainian band releases remix with Ed Sheeran — while fighting Russia
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit
item.description: Lead singer of the Ukrainian band Antytila says the song is about reuniting with loved ones the moment the war against Russia is over.

item.title: As Boris Johnson is cheered in Ukraine, U.K. voters prepare to punish his party
item.dc:creator: William Booth
item.description: Conservatives are expected to take a hit in Thursday's local elections, seen partly as a referendum on Johnson.

item.title: In Ukrainian villages, whispers of collaboration with the Russians
item.dc:creator: Robert Klemko
item.description: When the Russians came, some people seemed to help them; "the war showed who is who."

item.title: South Asia’s scorching heat wave comes as climate action stalls
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: South Asia is at the forefront of places in the world where experts believe life could literally become unbearable before the end of the century.

item.title: Russia steps up attacks on Ukraine’s railways, power stations
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault
item.description: The evacuations from the Azovstal steel plant come as Moscow reportedly prepares to annex Ukrainian territory, including Donetsk, Luhansk and Kherson.

item.title: Defense secretary says U.S. arms being put to ‘good use’ in Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.description: Ukraine's military is challenging Russian forces in the country's south and east, but strikes on civilian targets continue.

item.title: What is happening in Ukraine’s Mariupol, the city under Russian siege?
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger
item.description: Moscow had issued an ultimatum to Ukrainians remaining in the besieged port city: Surrender by midday and your life will be spared. Here’s what to know about Mariupol and the humanitarian catastrophe unfolding there.

item.title: Evacuees from Mariupol steel plant describe brutality of long siege
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: Dazed, haunted and traumatized, survivors struggled to explain the brutality: "I don’t have words... Nothing is real anymore."

item.title: Why is Ukraine’s Donbas region a target for Russian forces?
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall
item.description: Russia is preparing to formally claim vast new swaths of Ukrainian territory, including the eastern Ukrainian regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, the United States said.

item.title: Colombia extradites feared head of Gulf Clan to US
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Colombia has extradited the alleged head of the feared Gulf Clan, to the United States where he faces indictments in three federal courts

item.title: For marine biologist, Haitian gangs make work dangerous
item.dc:creator: Trenton Daniel and Pierre-Richard Luxama | AP
item.description: Powerful gangs in Haiti are making it difficult for marine biologist Jean Wiener to do on-the-ground conservation work aimed at mitigating the effects of climate change

item.title: For marine biologist, Haitian gangs make work dangerous
item.dc:creator: Trenton Daniel and Pierre-Richard Luxama | AP
item.description: Powerful gangs in Haiti are making it difficult for marine biologist Jean Wiener to do on-the-ground conservation work aimed at mitigating the effects of climate change

item.title: Mexican officials force airlines to use new, distant airport
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Transportation officials in Mexico will effectively force airlines to use a new, more distant airport that was one of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s pet projects

item.title: US resumes limited visa processing in Cuba after 4 years
item.dc:creator: Andrea RodrÍguez | AP
item.description: The U.S. Embassy in Havana has resumed processing visas for Cubans, though on a limited basis, more than four years after stopping consular services on the island amid a hardening of relations

item.title: DiCaprio, Ruffalo urge Brazilians to vote, irking Bolsonaro
item.dc:creator: Diane Jeantet | AP
item.description: Hollywood stars Leonardo DiCaprio and Mark Ruffalo have joined other celebrities making a final push for voters in Brazil to register before the Wednesday deadline

item.title: EXPLAINER: Why is Russia attacking Ukraine's railway system?
item.dc:creator: Barbara Surk | AP
item.description: Russia’s military has launched a string of attacks on Ukraine’s railway network, which has been vital for moving Western arms to Ukrainian forces, evacuating refugees and exporting food

item.title: Dutch king lays wreath, thousands attend remembrance event
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Dutch King Willem-Alexander has laid a wreath at a war memorial in Amsterdam during the first national commemoration of the country’s war dead since coronavirus restrictions were lifted earlier this year

item.title: Hecklers interrupt Israel PM's Memorial Day speech on unity
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Hecklers interrupted Israel’s prime minister for several minutes during a Memorial Day address in which he called for unity

item.title: WHO: COVID continues to decline, except in Americas, Africa
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: The World Health Organization says the number of newly reported coronavirus cases and deaths continued to fall in the last week, continuing a global decline that first began in March
